wordpressPost.title: WeSpire Employee Spotlight: Ellie Perkins Jowers
wordpressPost.content:
Any great organization requires outstanding people working together to fulfill that organization’s mission and vision. At WeSpire we are extremely fortunate to have a number of amazing colleagues, all working to bring purpose to employees at companies large and small around the world.

Every month we shine the spotlight on one member of the WeSpire team, giving you an ongoing glimpse into the workforce behind the most powerful employee-engagement platform on the market today.
Please say Hello to Ellie Perkins Jowers, WeSpire Sales Executive!

Q: What are the top five most-used apps on your phone?
A: Spotify, Instagram, Hopper, WhatsApp, Candy Crush
Q: What do you appreciate most about your childhood?
A: Spending the first few years of my life in Maine in a house off the grid that my parents built. I think it instilled a fundamental appreciation for living sustainably, well before it was cool to do so. I’m also very appreciative of having had a crew of chickens and goats for pets, who I used to read to every day after school.
Q: Tell us about your favorite teacher/coach/adult figure growing up. Why did they inspire you then, and what have you realized about them now?
A: My mother. She always challenged me to reach for my dreams, no matter how big, and told me I could do anything, be anything. She also always told me to trust the process. It’s taken me a long time to learn to do that (I’m still learning!), and as I’ve gotten older, I’ve realized just how right she was. Trusting the process remains the most valuable piece of advice I ever received, and something I practice daily.
Q: You have to go on vacation for two weeks, all expenses paid. Where to?
A: Botswana, Zimbabwe and South Africa ‘ I’ve always wanted to go to the Okavango Delta on a safari adventure. There is an open-air tree house I recently discovered that is in the middle of a game preserve in South Africa, where you can spend the night under the stars and safely above the wild animals roaming beneath. Sounds like a little slice of heaven.
Q: If you were in charge, what would you fix?
A: The fact that climate change is still contested.
Q: What’s the best Big Hairy Audacious Goal (BHAG) you ever heard of, and whose was it? (examples, for inspiration)
A: SpaceX’s goal of enabling human exploration and settlement of Mars. That’s pretty BHAG!
Q: When you’re at work, what’s the most interesting opportunity you have to solve a Big Hairy Audacious Problem (BHAP)?
A: To turn the 13% of employees around the world who are engaged at work to 100%. We are on the road toward solving that problem by connecting employees to meaning and purpose at work. It’s fascinating, crazy hard, and exhilarating all at once ‘ but I think we can do it.
Q: If you could hire a personal assistant tomorrow, what three questions would you ask him/or her in the job interview?
A: Why are you interested in this job? Are you passionate about making this world a more sustainable and just place? Do you drink wine? (The correct answer is yes.)
Q: What, if anything, is too serious to be joked about?
A: I would say anything about seriously hurting someone else is bad form. Other then that, I pretty much joke about everything. I’m known for my fabulous(ly bad) 4th grade sense of humor.
Q: What’s your favorite new vocabulary word?
A: Well it’s not a new word per se, but “purpose” has become my new favorite word, and I mean it in the way Aaron Hurst has defined it, relating to the purpose economy. I think Carol Cone recently summed it up best: Purpose has eclipsed CSR, sustainability, and other definitions, because’ it integrates the entire enterprise, powering it boldly from the inside out.
Q: What’s your favorite meal you made recently?
A: My mother’s famous beef and vegetable stew. It’s the easiest and best thing to make. I just throw vegetables, stew beef, spices and herbs into the crock pot in the morning, and voila! I come home in the evening to aromas of my childhood, cold winter nights in Maine, and all things delicious.
Q: Signature cocktail?
A: Dark & Stormy! Or a big, bold glass of red.
Q: Greatest extravagance?
A: Traveling to far-off places. My husband and I try to do one big adventure a year to a country we’ve never been.
(Editors’ note: we noticed! Morocco, London, and we hear Thailand is coming up soon!)
Q: Ideal pet?
A: I am very certain it doesn’t get better than golden doodles, specifically a certain golden doodle I know named Treacle.
Q: What would constitute a perfect day for you?
A: I would wake up listening to seagulls and lobster boats on the water in Maine. My husband John and dog Treacle and I would spend the day swimming in the ocean, reading in the sun (well, maybe not Treacle), and picnicking on my family’s boat. We’d then finish the day with a lobster cook out with our family and best friends, and spend the evening around a fire under the stars.
Q: If you were to die and come back as a person or thing, what do you think it would be?
A: A golden doodle. (Noticing a theme here’)
Q: If you could wake up tomorrow having gained any one quality or ability, what would it be?
A: Is this a real ability or imaginary? If it’s the latter, I would say to fly. If it’s the former, I would say to be able to sing like Jill Scott.

 
Mad lib bio snapshot:
Ellie Perkins Jowers was born in Damariscotta, ME. She launched her career at Eddie Bauer, and her favorite manager had a habit of trusting and believing in her absolutely. She joined WeSpire because she believed in the power of the company to make sustainability mainstream and fun, and was attracted by the BHAG of making every employee happy at work. In her spare time, she likes to swim in the ocean, go on adventures with her husband John and dog Treacle, eat brie, and go to Napa. Her colleagues at WeSpire have no idea that she loves learning about ancient cultures.
